validations_libs/cli/community.py.message:
I've created some dummy community validations.

   [vagrant@ibm-p8-kvm-03-guest-02 validations-libs]$ validation list --product community
   Validation config file found: /home/vagrant/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/validations-libs/validation.cfg
   +------------------+-------------------------------------------------+--------+------------+---------------+
   | ID               | Name                                            | Groups | Categories | Products      |
   +------------------+-------------------------------------------------+--------+------------+---------------+
   | test-am          | Brief and general description of the validation | []     | []         | ['community'] |
   | check-ram1       | Brief and general description of the validation | []     | []         | ['community'] |
   | check-ram        | Brief and general description of the validation | []     | []         | ['community'] |
   | undercloud-debug | Brief and general description of the validation | []     | []         | ['community'] |
   +------------------+-------------------------------------------------+--------+------------+---------------+

Now I try to create one community validation called `healthcheck-service-status` which exists when I use the --ansible-base-dir argument pointing out to the tripleo-validations repository:

   [vagrant@ibm-p8-kvm-03-guest-02 validations-libs]$ validation init healthcheck-service-status --ansible-base-dir ~/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/tripleo-validations/
   Validation config file found: /home/vagrant/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/validations-libs/validation.cfg
   An Ansible role called healthcheck_service_status already exist in:
   - /home/vagrant/community-validations/roles
   - /home/vagrant/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/tripleo-validations/roles/

Ok there is no issue here, it detected the role healthcheck_service_status present in /home/vagrant/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/tripleo-validations/roles/.

But when I mistype the path in the command line or using a wrong path in the config file, the community validation is created successfully:

   [vagrant@ibm-p8-kvm-03-guest-02 validations-libs]$ validation init healthcheck-service-status --ansible-base-dir ~/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/tripleo-validation
   Validation config file found: /home/vagrant/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/validations-libs/validation.cfg
   New role created successfully in /home/vagrant/community-validations/roles/healthcheck_service_status
   New playbook created successfully in /home/vagrant/community-validations/playbooks/healthcheck-service-status.yaml

And when I add stupid thing like this:

   [vagrant@ibm-p8-kvm-03-guest-02 validations-libs]$ validation init healthcheck-service-status --ansible-base-dir /tmp3
Validation config file found: /home/vagrant/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/validations-libs/validation.cfg
   An Ansible role called healthcheck_service_status already exist in:
   - /home/vagrant/community-validations/roles
   - /tmp3roles/   <-----

or:

   [vagrant@ibm-p8-kvm-03-guest-02 validations-libs]$ validation init healthcheck-service-status --ansible-base-dir ~/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/tripleo-validations/roles
   Validation config file found: /home/vagrant/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/validations-libs/validation.cfg
   An Ansible role called healthcheck_service_status already exist in:
   - /home/vagrant/community-validations/roles
   - /home/vagrant/devel/tripleo/UPSTREAM/tripleo-validations/rolesroles/  <--------

I know that we can't cover every stupid mistyping that a user like me could do (voluntarily or not :), but we absolutely have to avoid duplication. In the OpenStack/TripleO, you will always have validations coming from TV and VC (until VC will be retired) in /usr/share/ansible and if a customer decide to use the --validation-dir/--ansible-base-dir argument because he/they decided to store validations somewhere else + some community validations, it will become the mess IMO.

With the community validations the VF has now, I think that all the argument --validation-dir/--ansible-base-dir we spread over all the CLI sub commands became useless and could bring a lot of issue for you in the future.

My 2 cents.

What would stale-multiplier=3 mean? Does it mean that if the last measurement of a certain check is older than 3*ttl then that measurement is ignored? 

If yes, then if that last measurement indicated a failure then after 3*ttl the check's result will reset from 'fail' to 'pass'. Then some upper level service will send traffic towards this service and therefore the healtcheck will have new measurements. I'm OK with this intention but we need to document this meaning.

ok what I'm trying to address with this and I may be overthinking it is how to ensure the cache does not become invalid or out of sync with the state of nova.

im concerned that our last healthcheck for something is pass and that thing breaks in such a way that it is stuck in that state so after a period of time i wanted to remove that cached result.

i did not want to  do that right away as that woudl be equivlent of letting it be stuck in pass.

so after the TTL i wanted to consider the healthcheck as stale and report a waring state overall.
then after the stale_multiple*ttl we remove the value restorign to pass.

perhaps that is not the best way to adress this.

to answer your specific question

stale-multiplier=3 means if a check failed and it is not observed for 3*ttl seconds then we will remove it form the cache and the next time you check the endpoint  it wil reprot pass.

the logic behind that was if the failture was bad enough  to fullly lock up the agent it likely will lock up the binary or make it exit it will take the healthcheck endpoint with it.
but that likely is not what we want.

perhaps we only want to time out pass requslt or maybe i shoudl jsut remove this and the ttl entirly.

the ttl and exirey of ttl are really for the warn state.

to reconsile how we express warn without active probing. and in this case how to think about the staleness of data.

what do people think shoudl i remove the ttl and stale concept?

I agree that we need to distinguish between a clear fail (a request failed within a reasonable time) and unknown state ( there was no request in the near past so we don't know about the connectivity to the external services). So having a ttl defining the time a measurement is considered relevant, make sense to me. I'm not sure about having two levels though ( 1) ttl expired -> warn 2)n*ttl expired -> pass). I think it might be enough to simply reset to pass after ttl expired mapping the unknown state to pass and let the higher level service move to fail state if it cannot send traffic towards us.

I think it'd be good to make sure this actually works and it should be trivial to poke it from either curl in devstack or tempest. In fact, why wouldn't we make devstack use this to determine if the services are started? We already do some of that with ps and curl, IIRC.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I'm not sure I see a "big win" with this change, and wonder if this could break deployments that are not using auth_type==password, but rely on the other existing defaults.

The reason I came up with this is that in TripleO we include nova::cinder in the base nova manifest and because of that we have [cinder]project_name=services which does not align with the service project we use. These parameters are unused thus doesn't affect the behavior but IMO we should avoid leaving unamanged/unused parameters to avoid confusion or any unexpected issue caused by a future change.

Considering the effect on existin deployments, we generally use password authentication which requires the password parameter, so I believe this rarely would break any existing deployment. The auth_section might be another popular option but that doesn't require these credential parameters thus this change doesn't break it. Even if any of these parameters are needed, we allow users to override some parameters forcefully as a workaround.

Should we really unset the "services" project_name? This is the default spanning all Puppet modules but IIRC the actual default for this config opt is usually "service" which means this could be a breaking change if somebody doesn't set this explicitly.

I know that we for example assume the Puppet layer will set project_name=services and don't set it ourselves.
Thanks for clearing it up for me, now I'm understanding that it won't change the defaults.

The parameters like project_name can not be used unless the password is set. So setting these defaults without the password parameter has no effect.

The existing defaults (and the new default of auth_url) are populated when user gives the password parameter which is required to set up the credential. If the password parameter is not set then these parameters are not used, thus removing these defaults doesn't break anything.

We usually don't do this because we expect the credential is required when the class is loaded. However for this specific class we have a clear use case where the class is included but the credential is unnecessary, which I described in the commit message, and this allows such use case to work without unused parameters configured.
So if I understand it correctly, you are intending to do that is password is set the current defaults is still there?

Yes. I hope these test cases would explain that more clearly.

Why this size? And we want 8GB vs. 8GiB?

Docker requires considerable disk space for temporary files when loading images from archives. Once they are successfully loaded, the temp files are removed. An archive containing more than 8GB worth of images can lead to docker load failure due to lack of disk space.

ansible/roles/horizon/templates/horizon..message: Why? This will end up with the host owner & group

Both those changes are related to the issue I had copying the files into the container - they were copied with directories missing x, which resulted in horizon not starting up due to not being able to traverse themes directory.

When the configuration files are being copied over to controllers with  `horizon/tasks/config.yml` they are created as root:root with permissions set in the task.

Later on these files are copied into the container by `https://github.com/openstack/kolla/blob/master/docker/base/set_configs.py` as defined in `horizon/templates/horizon.json.j2` which is templated into config.json.
And the problem is that set_config.py while copies files correctly, it uses same permissions when copying directories - as defined in `config.json` it created all theme subdirectories without +x which caused them to be not traversable and app failed to start logging permission errors.

By switching to 644 in `Copying over custom themes` tasks we're creating files as root:root(644) on controllers, which later on results into them being root:root(644) on container - because of `preserve_properties=true`.

And since set_config.py does not mess with the permissions at all - it leaves +x on directories (which was present on controller located files).

It surely isn't ideal, maybe I can deal with it better?
Corrected missing execute on directories in set_configs.py in kolla (added as dependency for this change)
Maybe we need a Kolla change to treat /etc/openstack-dashboard/themes correctly? (e.g. set proper permissions for directories) Or a change to kolla_set_configs for dir_perm when recurse: true.

I know that we usually avoid to bump requirements on stable branches but without the changes landed by dogpile.cache 1.1.5 oslo.cache won't be able to recover from a connection issue in a Memcached cluster. This a problem for an HA context.

In other words if the used node of the cluster become down, oslo.cache won't switch to another node and won't recover. That will lead us to this bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.cache/+bug/1959562

The changes landed by 1.1.5 are new options passed to pymemcache[1] with the default value given by the pymemcache lib so I won't expect side effects introduced by these changes. The goal of the dogpile.cache changes is to allow us to configure manually these already existing value, that's all.

[1] https://github.com/sqlalchemy/dogpile.cache/commit/da490df9edae8c60e7ee3d577ac610efdffc5986

This bump is required by oslo.cache:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.cache/+/826594
Looks fine. Since it is a dev environment I am not too worried about security implications. Available alternatives to avoid the additional mount are clunky. So I agree with the method used here.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: FYI https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/825729 is trying to achieve the same thing, arguably in a nicer way. Might be worth a review

What is the motivation for this change?

As you may already know, libvirt will auto-enable SMM when requesting secure boot.  Secure boot is not really "secure" without SMM.

Also, libvirt ensures that SMM is not changed (on -> off or off -> on) on migration.

simple on ubuntu libvirt does not enable SMM mode when you request secure boot.
i have abandonded my patch in favor of 
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/825496
so that nova can work around the delta in libvirt behavior.

Note to self: take a closer look at the API design. A couple of things stand out:

- endpoint nouns should be singular
- payloads for POST operations should be in the body, not in the querystring
- operation on a specific existing item should identify the item in the path, e.g. DELETE /v2/arq/{uuid}

Somewhere there's an openstack API guidelines doc that outlines these best practices. Bug someone from the API SIG (like edleafe, cdent) for that doc.

* None of my POST ops have payloads in the query string.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/placement/#list-resource-providers

Where is the part where the devices are discovered on the host and their providers/inventories created in placement? Are they nested providers? Owned by cyborg (as opposed to nova)?

One possible approach for a first pass would be to let nova do the discovery in update_provider_tree by querying a cyborg API (GET /v2/devices?host={uuid} or something) and populating the provider tree there. So nova would "own" the devices. That would eliminate the asynchronous aspect and reduce the perceived footprint of the cyborg service in this implementation.

We will need to be able to change ownership of a provider at some point, possibly with a reshape operation, so this doesn't paint us into a corner wrt eventually having cyborg own the device RPs in placement.

> Is it your intent for "manual discovery" to be part of the real
 > thing for the first release? 

For Train release, we intend device discovery to be automatic.

 > Regarding the "footprint" comment, here's what I meant:
 > 
 > Cyborg doing the discovery asynchronously introduces more complexity to the 
 > picture. Need to handle e.g. bringup(racing/coordination when both services
 > are coming up; what happens if one service or the other is down/broken)... 

To prevent such conflicts, the operator must ensure that Nova and Cyborg handle disjoint sets of PCI IDs. Cyborg won't handle plain NICs while Nova won't handle FPGAs: so no conflicts there. For other devices (GPUs, QAT, ..), the operator must ensure that, if a Cyborg driver is installed for a class of devices with specific PCI vendor/product IDs, those IDs are not configured in the PCI whitelist. IOW, for a class of devices with a specific PCI ID (say vendor id 8086, product ID 3A95), it is not possible for some of those device instances to be managed by Nova and the rest by Cyborg.

Is it your intent for "manual discovery" to be part of the real thing for the first release? I'll grant you that that would greatly simplify a couple of the stickier aspects - like whether it's cyborg or nova that's responsible for discovery; how white/blacklisting is done, etc. - so it's not out of the question. But I think this document should make that clear either way.

Regarding the "footprint" comment, here's what I meant:

Cyborg doing the discovery asynchronously introduces more complexity to the picture. Need to handle e.g. bringup (racing/coordination when both services are coming up; what happens if one service or the other is down/broken)... Some of this obviously needs to be handled in a synchronous nova-driven design as well, but the cases are simpler. We also wouldn't have to cross the rubicon of having providers in a tree owned by different services just yet. Remember in Denver, just trying to land on how to mark ownership of a provider sent us off into the weeds for an hour.

Device discovery is not part of this pilot. Cyborg community wants to develop that code and it relies upon Placement API which is not the focus of the pilot branch. 

For now, a fake device is inserted into Cyborg 'by hand' and Placement API is called. Both are in the initial setup script [1].

Re. "let nova do the discovery ... reduce the perceived footprint of Cyborg" -- Cyborg would use standard Placement API. The footprint, as shown in [1], seems to be low already?

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/626420/2/nova-integ/initial_setup.sh

Device_profile is not unique in the database. So what if the name is duplicated?

Device profile is a 'flavor for devices'. When a flavor is created, a name is required but the id is optional [1]. Flavor id is really a string but could be used as integer or uuid. 

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=create-flavor-detail#create-flavor

Nova's flavor id is a legacy. For us, it is better to model the primary key field of a device profile as a name from Day 1. If there are additional device profile APIs that operate with UUIDs, that is ok too; we may need that for renaming device profiles in the future, for example.

From the operators' point of view, a device profile represents a certain configuration (e.g. 2 GPUs) or a workload (e.g. ML offload with 1 FPGA and 1 GPU -- making stuff up here).That is best represented as a name. That is not only more usable than UUIDs but also more consistent than flavor id usage today.

In the end-to-end flow, operators set device profile names in flavors, and so Nova calls Cyborg with a dp name rather than UUID. So, we need APIs with names.

Given above background, device profile names must be unique just as flavor IDs are unique.

cyborg/objects/arq.py.message:
Consider an example device profile:
  { "name": "mydp",
    "groups": [
        { "resources:FPGA": "2",
          "trait:foo": "required"
        },
        { "resources:GPU": "3",
          "trait:bar": "required"
        }
    ]
  }
The first request group will need 2 ARQs and 2nd one will need 3. So, ARQ : dp-group relation is N:1.

So, we should not copy the entire device profile object here. Instead, we only keep the name and request group id.

Also, since Nova queries Cyborg to get the device profile request groups and folds them into the request spec, carrying the request group(s) in the ARQ would be redundant.

But we do copy the request group for the ARQ into the ExtARQ, based on Nova developer feedback. This is similar to copying flavor into the request spec. This allows the device profile (or flavor) to be modified or deleted when running VMs are referencing them.
The attacxh_handle object has many fields that are internal to Cyborg and need/should not be exposed to Nova.

designate/central/service.py.message:
This concerns me because as I trace this code path down, there is a query->create->update chain (among others) here using sqlalchemy. If we take this outside of a transaction, the state may not be consistent at the zone create stage.
Can you tell me more about the error handling that broke?

The issue was that the transaction would cause a rollback when the zone was created that would cause the call to get interrupted at that stage since the rollback would ultimately fail (most likely because another call had just created the same zone). We don't actually need to rollback the zone since it's an admin zone and the worst case scenario we will end up with an empty zone.

update -> create could indeed use the transactions as in theory the api call could fail to populate and the record would still exist without the transaction. I moved the transaction further down the stack and this should fix the issue with the zone race conditions, while still keeping the important part the transaction helped to protect against.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Could this change potentially be an issue if the local dependencies differ from the dependency packages in the official repositories?

Your concern is reasonable. My understanding is that the Debian transition work is based on 'bullseye' distro, it means the local dependency also should be resolved in this distro. If this is true, there may no big issues.
The background of this commit is: when build 'intel-i40e' which depends on 'linux-kbuild-5.10', the build env installs 'kbuild-5.10.84-1' from the official repo 'http://deb.debian.org/debian bullseye main', actually it should install the 'kbuild-5.10.74-1.stx.1' from 'deb-local-build'. The reason is for the build env in chroot, both the official repo and deb-local-build & deb-local-binary have the same 'priority' 500, the depended package with higher version is selected, so the deb-local-build and deb-local-binary must be set to higher priority.
Yes. I suppose the dependencies will be the same across the repos so my worry is purely a corner case.

From the design, the key parameter that file 'STX_LOCALRC' passed to pkgbuilder is the 'REPOMGR_DEPLOY_URL', and minikube creats the file 'STX_LOCALRC' which is copied from the builder container's configmap. But I think you are right, adding a checking here will make the code stronger.
Yes, I agree the possibility is small, but not zero. So please add a check and error message.

As discussed, adding a TODO here - these should all be configured via puppet.
Yeah, should fix this but otherwise I think it looks good.

Do we really need for 4 workers to handle state changes? Events that can lead the rush/spike are:
  1. batch deployment (shouldn't need all 4)
  2. hourly unconditional subcloud states update
  3. management network outage (rare condition)

May want to check if the system is free of msg timeout error during soak test with 2 workers only and that dcmanager audit frequency is not compromised.

It's actually quite remarkable how much difference there is between 2 and 4 workers, from the perspective of the rabbitmq queue processing for dcmanager-state as well as the total time to process the offline subclouds. And we again see message timeout errors.

For the worst-case 1000 subcloud outage:
- The peak goes from ~70 messages in dcmanager-state queue for 4 workers up to ~700 with 2 workers.
- The total time to process the outage climbs from ~4m up to ~28m

distributedcloud/dcmanager/manager/subcl.message: I think this should go down at line 51 to keep it alphabetical, no?

So previously the DB would have been updated by the time we returned in line 1267/1251 below, but now we're going to send an RPC "cast" message and continue on before the DB is updated.  Is that valid?

It would be safer to use an RPC call here, at least until we've validated that a cast would not introduce race conditions.
Yes, I agree. I missed the cast vs. call here. I will change this and do some more testing, as this will also affect overall timings.
This entire method should be deleted - it was moved into subcloud_state_manager.py

distributedcloud/dcmanager/rpc/client.py.message: Have we validated all callers to ensure that a cast (which results in asynchronous DB updates) is acceptable and won't cause race conditions?

Previously all the calls were asynchronous, so rather than force all calls to now be synchronous, I think we can modify this API to allow for both cases (cast and call).

Existing RPC calls (before this commit) are all using cast so there should be no issues keeping them an asynchronous. 

However, you've identified the one call within subcloud_manager.py which was synchronous before and should probably remain synchronous, just to be on the safe side (i.e. at subcloud_manager.py line 1230).

Rather than having two separate API calls, I'd prefer to add an optional argument to the existing API to force a synchronous call (instead of cast). The argument would default to asynchronous since that is the main usage outside of subcloud_manager.py. Does that make sense?
I suggest we make a new RPC function update_subcloud_endpoint_status_sync() which does an RPC "call" to update_subcloud_endpoint_status.

manifests/neutron.pp.message: Because we don't require persistence of this ip, it would be much easier to use the same ip command here. As far as I've tested in my C9S vm ip command still works and can add an ip on the interface.
Yea we could probably get away with it here, though does it cause problems using nmcli?

Another problem was that nmcli doesn't add but replace the address. So this command removes the ip migrated from the loopback device... We are good as long as the ip is reachable and don't care about persistence, I replaced this by the ip command.

> I think if the ovs interface is down prior to applying the ip it'd be ok.
As far as I've tested the ip command works even if the interface is up, so I don't think we need to keep it down until we apply this IP.

> We should be able to add an ip at the vs_bridge level but i don't know how much effort we want to put into that
We can leave it now, because this is not something already implemented in the existing providers based on network script(or pure ovs commands)

yea i'm not a fan of that NetworkManager interaction. I think if the ovs interface is down prior to applying the ip it'd be ok.  We should be able to add an ip at the vs_bridge level but i don't know how much effort we want to put into that

A limitation with nmcli is that it doesn't apply the change immediately and we need to restart the connection as I updated the command. Unfortunately I could not find any option in nmcli command to make NetworkManager reload the updated defenition.

Benefit of ip command is that the change is applied immediately and we don't need that down/up steps.
